You need to send it into orbit and then deorbit it right down into the water next to the KSC and watch it from the shore line.

hahahhaha, this is awesome

Wow, that is beautiful!

Btw someone, can you give me a lecture one how Whackjob became so famous? His rep counter is insane and I hears his name often.

Cue indiana jones.
perfectly round? could I roll it on the surface with enough RCS and Torque?
I want to order 5! Do you deliver on weekends?

perfectly round? could I roll it on the surface with enough RCS and Torque?

You'd probably have to restrut the outside to make it more solid, but I don't see why this couldn't be done.

You'd probably have to restrut the outside to make it more solid, but I don't see why this couldn't be done.

I'd use UbioZur's welding mod, which would also solve a few other issues.
It's Thunderdum! Two Kerbals go in and only one comes out!

Btw someone, can you give me a lecture one how Whackjob became so famous? His rep counter is insane and I hears his name often.

He made an eloquent thread about coffee and regret that documented his progression in KSP. Normal players tend to build bigger and bigger until they get the basics, after which they start to focus on part efficiency. Whackjob learned the basics and opted to use that knowledge to build even bigger rockets.

That, coupled with his strangely competent computer (Seriously, I imagine it is cooled with liquid nitrogen and takes up half a room or something) has led to some truly glorious monstrosities.

He made an eloquent thread about coffee and regret that documented his progression in KSP. Normal players tend to build bigger and bigger until they get the basics, after which they start to focus on part efficiency. Whackjob learned the basics and opted to use that knowledge to build even bigger rockets.

That, coupled with his strangely competent computer (Seriously, I imagine it is cooled with liquid nitrogen and takes up half a room or something) has led to some truly glorious monstrosities.

Ah, the infamous coffee thread, where was I to see such a product of struggle and emotion.
